message.content: This question requires knowledge about decomposers in ecosystems. Canadian nightcrawlers, also known as earthworms, are decomposers that feed on dead organisms. They break down and consume organic matter, returning nutrients to the soil. Option (B) is incorrect because clouds are made up of water vapor and do not consume dead organisms. Option (C) is incorrect because satellites are man-made objects in space and do not have the ability to consume organisms. Option (D) is incorrect because robots are also man-made and do not have the ability to consume organisms.

This question requires basic knowledge about decomposers and their role in ecosystems. Dead organisms are consumed by decomposers, such as Canadian nightcrawlers, which break down the organic matter and recycle nutrients back into the environment. Options (B), (C), and (D) are incorrect because clouds, satellites, and robots do not have the biological capabilities to consume and decompose dead organisms.

This question requires knowledge about decomposers in ecosystems. Dead organisms are typically broken down and consumed by decomposers such as worms, specifically Canadian nightcrawlers in this case. Option (B) is incorrect because clouds are made up of water vapor and do not consume organisms. Option (C) is incorrect because satellites are man-made objects that orbit the Earth and do not eat anything. Option (D) is incorrect because robots are machines and do not have biological functions such as eating.

This question requires knowledge of decomposers in an ecosystem. Canadian nightcrawlers (a type of earthworm) are decomposers that feed on dead organisms. They help to break down and recycle nutrients in the soil. Options (B), (C), and (D) are not correct because clouds, satellites, and robots do not consume dead organisms in the same way that decomposers do.
